post_text: Happy Ampersand Day! This ancient logogram originated from "et," the Latin word for "and," and has since evolved into a million typographic variations used today. Learn more interesting & facts at https://bit.ly/2Zignxz.

Our ceramics instructor, Elaine Quave, has work featured in the latest edition of Ceramics Monthly! This piece is currently on display in the "Cutting Edge Clay" exhibition at the Clay Center of New Orleans.

From Ms. Quave, "This piece was directly influenced by my former professor Chad Curtis who was a visiting artist for my students at the SC Governor's School for the Arts and Humanities. He taught us all some digital design techniques and influenced my exploration into the digital realm. The work was also included in the Clemson anagama firing last year which gave it that beautiful wood fire surface and wouldn't exist without my explorations with the Potterbot."

TO THE CLASS OF 2020: A special message from Alonzo King

LINES Ballet founder Alonzo King has been called a visionary choreographer who is altering the way we look at ballet and was described by the New York Times as having “astonishing originality.” Mr. King was our Presidential Guest Artist in 2018 when he spent two days working with and inspiring our Govies. He is the recipient of numerous awards including an NEA choreographic fellowship, San Francisco Mayor's Award, a Jacob's Pillow Creativity Award, and Kennedy Center Master of Choreography. In addition to his work with The LINES Ballet, King's choreography is also in the repertoire of other dance companies including The Royal Swedish Ballet, Ballet Frankfurt, Ballet Béjart, Les Ballets de Monte-Carlo, Joffrey Ballet, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Hong Kong Ballet, North Carolina Dance Theatre, and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago.

TO THE CLASS OF 2020: A special message from Susan Heyward

Susan Heyward is a 2001 graduate of the Governor's School's Drama program. She attended Carnegie Mellon University and is an accomplished actress in television, film, and on stage. She played a recurring character in the HBO series Vinyl and a lead in Sony Playstation’s first original series, Powers. Susan made her Broadway debut in the 2013 production of The Trip to Bountiful and in 2018-2019 played Rose Granger-Weasley in the Broadway production of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. She also played the lead role of Tamika Ward in the final two seasons of Orange is the New Black.

post_text: The Drama Class of 2020 has mastered an especially challenging year of pre-professional actor training highlighted by sophisticated and moving performances in the short plays of Tennessee Williams, and our first ever musical, "The Robber Bridegroom." Their artistic journey has been fueled along the way by guest artists like master mask teacher Robert Francesconi, playwright and screenwriter David Rambo, and Emmy, Grammy and Tony winner André De Shields. In February, all 14 senior actors ventured to the Unified Theatre Auditions in Chicago, where they won acceptances and scholarships to the premier colleges and conservatories in the US and abroad. Check out their accomplishments at www.scgsah.org/class-of-2020.

Get ready for one of our most anticipated events of the year—PechaKucha Night!!! Yes, it's still happening, just in a slightly different way. Join us Wednesday evening at 7:30 p.m. to watch 10 of our soon-to-be-graduates inspire and educate us on something they're passionate about in these 20x20 presentations!

Not familiar with PechaKucha? These presentations feature 20 images set on 20-second timings to keep moving as the presenter tells a story, or tries out a theory, or confesses a quirk, or makes a case. This is the capstone project of our Humanities course.

post_text: We are very happy to have playwright, screenwriter and producer David Rambo back with us, even if virtually, for this week and next. Mr. Rambo has been a friend of the Governor's School since the beginning and has shared his expertise and experience with playwriting and script analysis with our Drama students for years. He's known for his work on television series such as CSI: Crime Scene Investigation, V, Revolution, and Empire, Will, and Claws. He's currently working on a new Netflix series, Tiny Pretty Things, slated to be released this year. Learn more about Mr. Rambo at http://www.davidrambo.com/.

It was a pleasure having Dr. John Lane, Director of the Division of Academic Affairs at the South Carolina Commission of Higher Education, as our Martin Luther King, Jr. Day speaker today! Dr. Lane echoed Dr. King's legacy as he urged us to work for greater access and equity of educational opportunities for all people. In regards to South Carolina's stats on education, he encouraged us to "use data, become acquainted with it, and remember that every data point is a human. If we can improve the data, we are improving lives." FUN FACT: Dr. Lane is a musician and a former student of Dr. Stephen Taylor!

Thank you, Dr. Lane, for joining us and informing us of the work of the SC CHE!

Yanko’s sensuous and immensely satisfying paintings draw the viewer into a labyrinth of both complexity and caprice. Densely and brightly layered, architectonic yet playful, simultaneously lucid and oblique, the language of painting that Yanko has developed in his fine art practice over the course of his career is instantly recognizable as uniquely his own.

post_text: This past Friday, our students had the opportunity to spend some quality time with Phillip Boykin—SCGSAH Honors Program alum, Grammy-winning and Tony-nominated performer, and star of “Once on This Island!" He spoke at our community meeting about growing up in #Greenville and his life and career as an artist. Mr. Boykin also led a vocal masterclass and participated in a Q&A session with our students. It was a great day with an incredible artist. Thanks for joining us, Mr. Boykin!

post_text: Congratulations to our beloved library director, Norman Belk, who is retiring after 13 years of unparalleled service to the Governor's School! He is truly an irreplaceable member of our community who made the library the very heart of this campus. Mr. Belk also played a significant role in the development of the Greenville County Library System and the Hughes Main Library and has been a sustaining member of the South Carolina Library Association for over 30 years. We will miss Mr. Belk very much, but we are so happy he can now enjoy some well-earned downtime!

post_text: Today marks Rusty Godfrey’s 28th year of teaching! Mr. Godfrey is our interim academics department chair and social studies instructor and has been teaching at the Governor’s School since 2002. He’s taught nearly 3500 students over the course of his career! FUN FACT: Mr. Godfrey is a lover of jazz and Star Trek. He is also a licensed local pastor for the United Methodist Church.
